title: SPOT-RASTR - A Cryo-EM Specimen Preparation Technique that Overcomes Problems with Preferred Orientation and the Air/water Interface
content: Recent advancements in cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) have expanded its efficiency, leading to an upsurge in high-resolution structure determinations. The focus has shifted towards intricate specimens, challenging existing processing software capabilities, and necessitating innovative methodologies. Cryo-EM sample preparation encounters hurdles such as high concentration demands, difficulty in entering EM substrate holes, and degradation at the air/water interface [1]. While diverse samples behave uniquely during plunge-freezing, complications like aggregation, denaturation, and preferred orientations arise, primarily attributed to air-water interface interactions. Various strategies aim to enhance sample preparation at different workflow stages, including optimizing biochemical levels, grid selection, or using alternative support materials [2â€“5]. Tubular samples present a promising solution, minimizing air/water interface challenges. Lipid-modified tubules can serve as substrates for specimen preparation, offering a potential breakthrough in overcoming cryo-EM sample preparation difficulties.
